Maximum power is delivered when:

R_L = R_th

The load resistance equals the Thévenin (source) resistance.

This is called 'impedance matching' or 'resistance matching'.

When R_L = R_th:

P_max = V_th² / (4R_th)

Or equivalently:
P_max = I_N² × R_N / 4

(where I_N = V_th/R_th)

At R_L = R_th:

Efficiency = 50%

Half the power goes to the load.
Half the power is lost in R_th.

You CANNOT have both maximum power AND high efficiency!

For any load R_L:

η = R_L / (R_th + R_L)

Efficiency increases as R_L increases.

• R_L = R_th → η = 50%
• R_L = 9×R_th → η = 90%
• R_L → ∞ → η → 100%

Power to load:

P_L = V_th² × R_L / (R_th + R_L)²

This peaks at R_L = R_th.

At both R_L = 0 and R_L = ∞:
P_L = 0

Match impedances when:

• Signal power is small (audio, RF)
• Source isn't depleted
• Want maximum signal strength

Examples:
• Antenna systems (50Ω)
• Audio amplifiers
• Sensor interfaces

Don't match when:

• High efficiency is critical
• Power levels are high
• Energy cost matters

Examples:
• Power grid (want η > 95%)
• Battery systems
• Motor drives

Instead: Make R_L >> R_th

Current: I = V_th / (2R_th)

Load voltage: V_L = V_th / 2

Load power: P_L = V_th² / (4R_th)

Source power loss: Same as P_L!

Total from source: 2P_L

For AC with Z_th = R_th + jX_th:

Maximum power when:
Z_L = Z_th* = R_th - jX_th

(Complex conjugate)

• Resistive parts match
• Reactive parts cancel

You must CHOOSE:

| Goal | Set R_L |
|------|---------|------|
| Max Power | = R_th | η = 50% |
| η = 67% | = 2R_th | P = 89% max |
| η = 90% | = 9R_th | P = 36% max |

Can't maximize both!
